questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following factors will increase the risk of a patient developing gastric 
carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for gastric carcinoma. Aspirin, which is a COX inhibitor, is protective against gastric cancer. Eating refrigerated food has reduced the need for salting of food for preservation, and thus 
reduced the incidence of gastric cancer. Males are more commonly affected as compared to females.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population is the antrum. This is 
because H. pylori infections are relatively more prevalent in Asian countries and are associated 
with carcinoma of the body and distal stomach than the proximal stomach. However, in western countries, the proximal stomach is the most common site. This is attributed 
to a lesser prevalence of untreated H.pylori infections and a greater burden of chronic GERD and 
obesity in western countries. 448 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A man presents to the hospital with a 3-day history of haematemesis. Upper GI endoscopy 
reveals multiple gastric polyps and a positive urease breath test. Which type of polyp is he 
most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
The given history and investigations are suggestive of Helicobacter pylori infection. The polyps 
most commonly associated with H. pylori infection are hyperplastic polyps. Hyperplastic polyps usually regress following H. pylori eradication therapy. Benign gastric polyps are classified into two groups: • Neoplastic: • Adenoma • Fundic gastric polyp • Non- neoplastic: • Hyperplastic polyp (most common) • Inflammatory polyp • Hamartomatous polyp Note: The terms hyperplastic polyp and metaplastic polyp refer to the same lesion, however, 
'hyperplastic polyp' is a preferred term.

questions.question:
Question 4: An elderly patient who presented with abdominal discomfort and weight loss was diagnosed 
with type I gastric cancer according to Lauren’s classification. Which of the following is not 442 
Sold by @itachibot true regarding this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type I gastric cancer is associated with hematogenous spread. Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer pathology as either type I (intestinal) or type II (diffuse), 
based on differences in etiology, epidemiology, and pathology. Intestinal type of gastric cancer 
shows hematogenous spread, whereas diffuse-type shows transmural and lymphatic spread.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following genetic mutations is least likely to be seen in a patient with an 
intestinal type of gastric cancer?

options.b: Loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene
options.c: Under expression of transforming growth factor 
options.d: Loss of heterozygosity at the bcl-2 gene

questions.explanation:
In the intestinal type of gastric cancer, several growth factors may be overexpressed, including 
transforming growth factor , the epidermal growth factor, and vascular endothelial growth factor 
(VEGF). Molecular pathologies seen in Intestinal type: • Mutation or loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene or in -catenin • Inactivation of p53 • Loss of heterozygosity at the BCL-2 gene • Microsatellite instability Molecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type: 449 
Sold by @itachibot • Mutation of E- cadherin • Inactivation of p53

questions.question:
Question 6: A man, presented with multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting containing undigested food 
particles within one-hour post meals. On physical examination, he was found to be anemic 
and cachexic. CECT abdomen revealed diffuse infiltration of a neoplastic growth into the 
stomach wall. What Bormann’s classification does this tumor belong to?
questions.explanation:
The history and investigation findings are suggestive of gastric outlet obstruction caused by a 
diffusely infiltrating type of gastric carcinoma. This is commonly known as linitis plastica and it is 
classified as type IV in Bormann’s classification system.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient was found to have a tumor extending up to 1cm below the gastroesophageal 
junction on EUS. According to the Siewert classification, which stage of carcinoma does she 
have?
questions.explanation:
The patient is likely to have a Siewert type II lesion. This include tumors with the center located 1 
cm above and 2 cm below the GE junction. • Type I: Adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus - the epicenter of the lesion is 1-5 cm above GEJ • Type II: Adenocarcinoma of the cardia - the epicenter of the lesion is up to 1 cm above and 2 cm 
below GEJ • Type III: Subcardial type adenocarcinoma - the epicenter of the lesion is 2-5 cm below GEJ

questions.question:
Question 8: A woman presented to the gastroenterology OPD with significant weight loss, fatigue, and a 
bloating sensation for the past 8 months. A detailed workup was done, and she was diagnosed 
with early gastric carcinoma. All of the following structures can be involved in this stage 
except:
questions.explanation:
In early gastric cancer, there is no involvement of muscularis propria. Gastric cancer can be classified as early and advanced gastric cancer, based on the extent of 
involvement. Early gastric cancer involves: • Mucosa (including muscularis mucosa) • Submucosa • +/- lymph nodes Advanced gastric cancer involves: • Muscularis layer • +/- adjacent structures 450 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: An Asian man who is a known smoker presented to the OPD with dysphagia, nausea, and loss 
of appetite. Endoscopy revealed a tumor arising from the stomach. Which of the following 
statements is false regarding TNM staging for this condition?

options.a: In T4 lesions, tumor perforates the serosa.
options.b: Metastasis in 1-5 lymph nodes is N1 disease.
options.c: Tumor invades adjacent organs in T4 lesions.
options.d: Metastasis in > 15 lymph nodes is N3b.

questions.explanation:
The clinical features and endoscopy findings point to a diagnosis of gastric carcinoma. According 
to TNM staging of gastric carcinoma, N1 disease refers to metastasis to 1-2 regional lymph nodes.

questions.question: Question 10: A positive Troisier’s sign refers to the involvement of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Troisier’s sign refers to the enlargement of left supraclavicular lymph nodes, which is also known 
as Virchow nodes. It is seen in patients with gastric cancer metastasis, caused by the spread of the 
tumor via the thoracic duct into the left supraclavicular lymph nodes. It is a sign of advanced 
cancer. It is one of the atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma. Other atypical presentations of gastric 
carcinoma include • Sister Mary Joseph nodule • Due to periumbilical metastasis. • See in both gastric cancer (most common) and ovarian cancer. • Krukenberg’s tumor • Bilateral ovarian metastasis • Due to retrograde lymphatic spread • Irish nodule • Left axillary lymphadenopathy. • Blumer shelf nodules • Pelvic metastasis into the pouch of Douglas/ retrovesical pouch 451 
Sold by @itachibot • Sign of advanced gastric carcinoma • Felt on digital palpation • Trosseau syndrome • Migratory thrombophlebitis • Leser Trelet sign • Multiple seborrheic keratoses • Resolves after gastrectomy • Tripe palms • Hyperkeratosis palm. The image below shows an elderly man with left supraclavicular lymph nodes enlarged.

questions.question:
Question 11: 444 
Sold by @itachibot A male patient who was diagnosed with early gastric cancer is planned for endoscopic 
mucosal resection. Which of the following features would make him a poor candidate for this 
procedure?
questions.explanation:
Endoscopic mucosal resection for gastric cancer should not be performed in case of ulcerated 
gastric cancer. Indications for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer: • Tumor smaller than 2cm • Tumor limited to the mucosa • No lymphovascular invasion • No ulceration • Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology. If any of these are not fulfilled, then gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated. 452 
Sold by @itachibot For a proximal gastric carcinoma a total gastrectomy is done and for distal gastric carcinoma, 
subtotal gastrectomy is ideal. For advanced carcinoma gastrectomy can be done as a palliative 
treatment.

questions.question:
Question 12: According to the Japanese classification for gastric carcinoma, which of the following is the 
level 5 lymph node?
questions.explanation:
Suprapyloric nodes are the level 5 gastric lymph nodes. The japanese classification for gastric carcinoma (JCGC) staging system divided lymph nodes into 
16 groups based on the likelihood of metastasis from the primary tumor and removal of lymph 
nodes during gastrectomy. The surgery for gastric cancer involves the removal of the primary tumor and lymph nodes. 
Depending on the extent of lymph node stations removed, the surgery may be either D1 or D2 
gastrectomy. D1 gastrectomy involves the removal of lymph node stations 1-6. D2 gastrectomy involves the 
removal of lymph node stations 1-11.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with gastric adenocarcinoma is posted for surgery. What is the extent of negative 
margin you should remove around the tumor for this patient?
questions.explanation:
In surgical resection of gastric cancer, at least 5cm of negative margin should be removed around 
the tumor.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with vague abdominal pain and feeling of a lump in the abdomen for the 
past 1 year. He was found to have a tumor arising from the stomach on CT scan. Biopsy of the 
lesion showed tumor cells positive for CD117 and CD34. What is the most likely origin of the 
tumor?
questions.explanation:
The clinical and histopathological features are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor 
(GIST). They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal. 453 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a component of Carney's triad?
questions.explanation: Carney's triad does not include pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Carney’s triad consists of: • Extra-adrenal paraganglioma • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor • Pulmonary chondroma

questions.question:
Question 16: A 45-year-old man presents with epigastric pain and intermittent vomiting for 2 months. He 
was inadequately treated for H. pylori infection 3 months back. The patient is HIV positive 
and is on ART for the same. Endoscopy reveals a fungating mass arising from the stomach. 
Biopsy of the lesion shows tumor cells positive for CD20. Which of the following is false 
regarding this tumor?

options.a: Stomach is the most common organ involved.
options.c: Fundus is the most common site involved
options.d: It is associated with H. pylori infections

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of gastric lymphoma. The most common type of gastric lymphoma is non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). Among NHL, 
the most common type is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) (55%), followed by gastric 
mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, mantle cell and 
follicular lymphoma. Immunodeficiencies and H. pylori infections are risk factors for the development of primary 
diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The antrum is the most common site for gastric lymphoma. The stomach is the most common 
organ to develop lymphoma in the GI system. Treatment: • Combined modality - chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiotherapy • The most common chemotherapeutic combination for DLBCL is R-CHOP [Rituximab, 
Cyclophosphamide, Hydroxydaunomycin (doxorubicin), Oncovin (vincristine), prednisone].

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not an indication for surgery in a patient with gastric lymphoma?
questions.explanation: Intractable pain is not an indication for surgery in the case of gastric lymphoma. Indications for surgery in gastric lymphoma: • Patients with symptomatic recurrence or treatment failure • Patients who develop complications, such as bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, and perforation

questions.question:
Question 18: 446 
Sold by @itachibot A woman underwent a total gastrectomy 5 months ago for gastric carcinoma. Which of the 
following is the most common metabolic complication expected in her?
questions.explanation:
The most common metabolic complication seen after gastrectomy is iron deficiency anemia. 454 
Sold by @itachibot Although absorption of iron occurs primarily in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, it needs an 
optimum acidic environment for absorption. Hence, due to a combination of decreased iron 
intake, impaired iron absorption, and chronic blood loss, there is iron deficiency anemia. The 
addition of iron supplements to the patient’s diet corrects iron deficiency anemia. Complications of gastrectomy: • Dumping syndrome: early and late • Nutritional deficiencies- Iron deficiency anemia (most common), Vit B12 deficiency, and 
osteoporosis • Diarrhea • Duodenal stump leak/blow out • Bile reflux gastritis and esophagitis • Gall stones • Roux syndrome

questions.question:
Question 19: A 50-year-old male presented with upper GI bleeding, abdominal pain, and a palpable 
abdominal mass. An endoscopic biopsy revealed a 5 cm tumor, with a high mitotic rate and 
c-KIT positivity in the body of the stomach. Which of the following is the best treatment of 
choice?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of GIST with a high risk of malignancy (high mitotic rate). 
The best treatment modality in the given scenario is surgical resection (with negative margin) 
followed by imatinib. Imatinib is a tyrosine-kinase inhibitor. Option A: Surgical resection + surveillance is done for GIST with a low risk of malignancy. The 
risk of malignancy is determined by 2 factors - the size of the tumor and mitotic index. Option C: Lymphadenectomy (D2 gastrectomy) is not done in GIST as it does not show lymph 
node metastasis. Option D: GIST is radioresistant and does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. It only 
responds to imatinib. If imatinib resistant, sunitinib or sorafenib is given.

questions.question:
Question 20: The gastrectomy specimen of a 56-year-old woman who underwent total gastrectomy showed 
HER2/neu positivity. Which among the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Trastuzumab is the drug of choice in carcinoma stomach with HER2/neu mutation. Trastuzumab 
is a HER2 receptor antagonist. Chemotherapy options in carcinoma stomach: • With HER2/neu mutation - Trastuzumab/Herceptin • With PD-L1 gene mutation - Pembrolizumab • Oral chemotherapy drugs: • Tegafur • Oteracil • Gimeracil 455 
Sold by @itachibot • Conventional chemotherapy drugs used are 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin. Chemotherapy is offered for patients with lymph node-positive disease and advanced gastric 
carcinoma (T3 and beyond) as part of palliative treatment. 456 
Sold by @itachibot Metabolic & Bariatric Surgery
